questions.question_text:
Your organization has recently gone Google, but you are not syncing Groups yet. You plan to sync all of your Active Directory group objects to Google Groups with a single GCDS configuration.
Which scenario could require an alternative deployment strategy?

choices.A: Some of your Active Directory groups have sensitive group membership.
choices.D: Some of the Active Directory groups do not have email addresses.
choices.C: Some of the Active Directory groups have members external to organization.
choices.B: Some of the Active Directory groups do not have owners.

discussion.content:
D. https://support.google.com/a/answer/7177266?hl=en

"All groups in a Google domain are referenced by an email address. You must ensure that all the security groups you want to synchronize have a valid mail attribute defined."
C is correct
D, https://support.google.com/a/answer/7177266?hl=en
Is not D? Why is C ???

questions.question_text:
Your Chief Information Security Officer is concerned about phishing. You implemented 2 Factor Authentication and forced hardware keys as a best practice to prevent such attacks. The CISO is curious as to how many such email phishing attempts you've avoided since putting the 2FA+Hardware Keys in place last month.
Where do you find the information your CISO is interested in seeing?

discussion.content:
Should be C
https://support.google.com/a/answer/7492330?hl=en

Selected Answer: C
C. It is a report that actually exists.

Selected Answer: C
A isn't even a thing. It's C.

Selected Answer: C
correct answer is C

Selected Answer: C
correct answer is C
C: Where would you find this information if the CISO asks? The most efficient way is using the Security Panel - ref: https://support.google.com/a/answer/7492330?hl=en
C is correct
C is correct
Should be C definitely.
C is correct answer here.

choices.B: Apps > G Suite > Gmail > Phishing Attempts
choices.A: Security > Advanced Security Settings > Phishing Attempts

questions.question_text:
Your company has just received a shipment of ten Chromebooks to be deployed across the company, four of which will be used by remote employees. In order to prepare them for use, you need to register them in G Suite.
What should you do?

discussion.content: A is correct

Vote D (https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/4600997?hl=en)
Chromebook Enterprise devices with Chrome version 80 or later preinstalled automatically prompt users to enroll. If theyâ€™re not prompted to enroll, users should press Ctrl+Alt+E.

comments.content: Actually the question says "you need to enroll them", so A is right!

discussion.content:
A is correct option
https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/4600997?hl=en

choices.C: Turn on the chromebook and log in as a Chrome Device admin. Press Ctrl+Alt+E to begin enterprise enrollment.
choices.B: In Chrome Management | Device Settings, enable Forced Re-enrollment for all devices.
choices.D: Instruct the employees to log in to the Chromebook. Upon login, the auto enrollment process will begin.
choices.A: Turn on the Chromebook and press Ctrl+Alt+E at the login screen to begin enterprise enrollment.

questions.question_text:
All Human Resources employees at your company are members of the "HR Department" Team Drive. The HR Director wants to enact a new policy to restrict access to the "Employee Compensation" subfolder stored on that Team Drive to a small subset of the team.
What should you do?

choices.A: Use the Drive API to modify the permissions of the Employee Compensation subfolder.
choices.D: Move the subfolder to the HR Director's MyDrive and share it with the relevant team members.
choices.B: Use the Drive API to modify the permissions of the individual files contained within the subfolder.
choices.C: Move the contents of the subfolder to a new Team Drive with only the relevant team members.

discussion.content: Should be C

Selected Answer: C
This question is outdated, C was the right choice, but now you can change subfolder permissions in any Team Drive

Selected Answer: C
"Inherited permissions can't be removed from a file or folder in a shared drive". ref:
https://developers.google.com/drive/api/v3/manage-sharing
C is correct

As stated, "Inherited permissions can't be removed from a file or folder in a shared drive", Should be C
https://developers.google.com/drive/api/v3/manage-sharing
What would be the appropriate response?

comments.content:
You cannot make Team Drives subfolders more or less restrictive than the top level folder. 
https://support.google.com/drive/thread/25570677?hl=en
nwk is right

according to this link [https://support.google.com/a/answer/7662202?hl=en#zippy=%2Cmoving-and-sharing-files%2Chow-to-use-folder-sharing%2Chow-does-the-sharing-experience-work%2Cwho-can-share-folders%2Cset-file-sharing-permissions] you CAN set permission at a folder and file level. So A or B are viable options. Also, this link [https://developers.google.com/drive/api/v3/manage-sharing] shows that the Drive API does support file and folder sharing. So I would select B as this option meets the requirements. Option C is a workaround
Typo, I would select A, not B as its better to manage permission at a folder level than a file level.

discussion.content: B is correct

questions.question_text:
Your company uses a whitelisting approach to manage third-party apps and add-ons. The Senior VP of Sales & Marketing has urgently requested access to a new
Marketplace app that has not previously been vetted. The company's Information Security policy empowers you, as a G Suite admin, to grant provisional access immediately if all of the following conditions are met:
âœ‘ Access to the app is restricted to specific individuals by request only.
âœ‘ The app does not have the ability to read or manage emails.
âœ‘ Immediate notice is given to the Infosec team, followed by the submission of a security risk analysis report within 14 days.
Which actions should you take first to ensure that you are compliant with Infosec policy?

discussion.content:
C
Control which third-party & internal apps access G Suite data
https://support.google.com/a/answer/7281227?hl=en

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Infosec is the key, think security wise. https://support.google.com/a/answer/7281227?hl=en
C is correct
the correct is C
C is correct option.

choices.C: Add the Marketplace app, then review the authorized scopes in Security > Manage API client access.
choices.D: Search the G Suite support forum for feedback about the app to include in the risk analysis report.
choices.A: Move the Senior VP to a sub-OU before enabling Marketplace Settings > "Allow Users to Install Any App from G Suite Marketplace."
choices.B: Confirm that the Senior VP's OU has the following Gmail setting disabled before whitelisting the app: "Let users delegate access to their mailbox."
